results.title: Botanic man
results.brief_description: An amazing 10-part series, tracing the evolution and adaptation of life on earth. The programs take a botanical point of view because it is the plants that form the basis of the energy web which enables life as we know it to exist in this world.
results.description: An amazing 10-part series, tracing the evolution and adaptation of life on earth. The programs take a botanical point of view because it is the plants that form the basis of the energy web which enables life as we know it to exist in this world.

results.title: Boston: the art of a city
results.creator_credit: Cinemagraphics, Yale Marc and Jim Herzig
results.brief_description: Surveys professional, amateur, and personal cultural life of Metropolitan Boston, including the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Boston Ballet, the Opera Company, folk dancing, singing, painting, and other activities.

results.title: Boston Symphony Orchestra
results.brief_description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra in Japan in 1960, conducted by Charles Munch and Aaron Copland, includes performances of sections of major works with narration kept to a minimum. Includes complete movements or sections from the following: Easley Blackwood Jnr - “Symphony No. 1”; Hector Berlioz - “Symphony Fantastique”; Aaron Copland - “The Tender Land”; Claude Debussy - Symphonic Poem “La Mer”.

results.title: Bossing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Plumbing”.
Instructional film demonstrating the skill of bossing - flowing or drifting of lead from one part of sheet to another by blows from hardwood instrument.

results.title: Borrowed faces
results.brief_description: Covers the audition process at the 1979 Colorado Shakespeare Festival from the viewpoints of the actors and directors. The actors’ feelings about acting, about themselves and the roles they play are examined, as well as how they handle rejections; the directors talk about how they decide which actors to cast in which roles. The final scene shows the successful actors playing the roles for which they auditioned.

results.title: Borneo's cathedral of trees
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough goes in search of wildlife in the Borneo jungle, and finds the world’s largest flower; night creatures such as the tarsier, the slow loris, and the pangolin; and the nomadic Puran tribe who hunt for food using deadly blowpipes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Born to ride
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, Catherine Marciniak, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
Mechanic Doug Sunderland has been riding motorbikes for 60 years. At 75 years of age, he sets out on a journey to ride through India and Nepal, overcoming ill-health and a collision to celebrate the new Millennium and 2 million kilometres in the saddle. During his voyage, he recounts the 6 years he spent in an orphanage, suggesting it fueled his desire to seek nature and open spaces. Doug also visits Rumtek Monastery in Sikkim. Cinematography by Catherine Marciniak. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

results.title: Born to boats
results.brief_description: Depicts the British as a people born to boats. Shows designing, process of vuilding, and use of yachts, lifeboats, racing shells, and other small craft. Scenes include yacht-racing at Cowes, Uffa Fox designing new speed-boats including Donald Campbell in his turbo jet boat “Bluebird” with his record breaking run at 204 mph, and rowing on the Thames.
